channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2025030027
item.description:
Report E-2025030027

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-01
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: QUALITY CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: DRIVER ENTERED THE LOADING AREA WITH INTERNAL VALVE OPEN, EXTERNAL VALVE OPEN AND WASHOUT CAP OFF. ALL SHOULD HAVE BEEN CLOSED. STARTED LOADING WHEN PRODUCT SPILLED INTO CONTAINMENT AREA. CLEANED UP SPILL BY SHIPPER

item.title: Report I-2025020068
item.description:
Report I-2025020068

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-01T21:20:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-13
  • City: Portland
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11201
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Order was placed for material for 1900 gallons. Tank was a 1550-gallon tank, drivers are instructed to fill tanks to 7/8 to allow room for them to blow out their lines. The driver arrived onsite and hooked up to the tank without any incident. o l. On most occasions the entire load of material should fit into the tank and near the end of the load is when you tend to have issues where the tank gets full. Driver filled tank and initially reported that there was a 5-15 gallon spill out of the top of the tank when he was blowing out his line. •. On 01/22/25 when we received the paperwork and telemetry on the tank it was calculated the actual amount of the spill was 642 gallons. This is above the RQ of 1 0001bs. This was reported to NCR# 1422616 on 01/22/25. A clean-up crew (TAZ Environmental) was contracted to clean the containment area. PVS learned that Ferric Chloride had been pumped into frac tanks from containment and needed to be cleaned out and contracted a new remediation company Miller Septic was contracted. Clean-up of the Ferric Chloride material has been completed.

item.title: Report E-2025020366
item.description:
Report E-2025020366

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: BLAKESBURG
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: W2 LOGISTIC INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 50000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 14, 2025, a W2 Logistic, Inc tractor trailer was involved in a motor vehicle incident that resulted in a cargo release. The trailer was hauling various drums and totes of non-hazardous, non-regulated, and hazardous UN1760, Corrosive liquids. Approximately 300-500-gallons of various products released to the environment. Local authorities, Mike Lamb from Emergency Management & Homeland Security, and Deran’s Towing Service were on site. Transportation Spill Solutions (TSS) reviewed the report from the Fire Department. According to the report, Mike Lamb and the Fire Department’s Hazmat Team conducted the initial cleanup of the release. The FD indicated that there (3) 55-gallon drums, (3) 250-gallon totes, and (2) 5-gallon buckets near the nose of the trailer. Only (2) 250-gallon totes and (1) 55-gallon drum was leaking inside the trailer. There were (4) 55-gallon drums and (1) 250-gallon tote outside the trailer. FD transferred material into (1) 55-gallon drum, (2) 95-gallon drums, (2) 65-gallon drums, and (1) 35-gallon drum. There was also a hydraulic oil release that was cleaned. All drums were labelled and staged on the side of the roadway.
